did.unittitle: Russia's War: blood upon the snow

note.p: Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: Video Tape x 5. 10 episodes in total. Episode 1: The Darkness Descends: Lenin's legacy - Stalin's rise to power; 2: The Hour Before Midnight: the dark days leading to war; 3: The Goths Ride East: Barbarossa: Nazi invasion of Russia; 4: Between Life and Death: the tragic seige of Leningrad; 5: The Fight from Within: Minsk ghetto and partisan movement; 6: The Cauldron Boils: Stalingrad fights for survival; 7: The Citadel: the great Kursk tank battle; 8: The False Dawn: the end is near - Poland is sacrificed; 9: The Fall of the Swastika: the death of Hitler - victory at last; 10: The Cult of Personality: the final days of Stalin

Notes: Copied from video 40 Contents: 1. Gymnastics Parade. July 1939, Red Square, Moscow 2. Section on Eisenstein. Shows plans and drawings for Ivan Grozny and a scene with Prokofiev at the piano 3. Persimfans, 1927, with Prokofiev playing (silent) 4. Prize giving ceremony with Prokofiev, Khachaturian, Shebalin etc. (silent) 5. Prokofiev at his dacha in 1946. Plays an extract from the Waltz Suite and is then interviewed (with sound) 6. About the Association of Soviet Composers with an exhibition on Prokofiev. Shows extracts from the 1946 film 7. Repeat of the 1946 film with interview

did.unittitle: Lermontov

note.p: Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: Copied from Video 42 06/03/2007 Albert Gendelshtein’s film is a portrait of the great nineteenth century Russian writer and poet Mikhail Lermontov, the inheritor of Pushkin’s mantle, who, like his mentor, died in a duel at the age of twenty six. Lermontov’s affection for the serfs and peasantry, and his criticisms of the Tsar, endeared him to the post-revolutionary Soviet regime. Prokofiev was one of two composers for the film (the other being Venedict Pushkov). Featuring Prokofiev’s two pieces, Contradance and Mephisto Waltz.

did.unittitle: Tonya: nashi devushki

note.p: Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: Copied from Video 41 06/03/2007 Abram Room’s Tonya tells the heroic story of a telephone operator who sacrifices her life by drawing Soviet artillery fire onto the Nazi weapons that are stored near her office. Like Room’s earlier film A Severe Young Man, Tonya was banned by the Soviet authorities. Prokofiev wrote the score in August 1942.

did.unittitle: From The Glinka Museum, 2003 (compilation)

note.p: Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: SEE DVD 13 (transferred 27/02/2007) Donated by Irina Medvedeva (Glinka Museum) in 2003 CONTENTS: 00'00: Gymnastics parade of July 1939 on the Red Square, Moscow 09'27'': Section on Sergei Eisenstein. Shows plans and drawings for Ivan Grozny and a scene with Prokofiev at the piano 10'59'': Persimfans, 1927 (soundless), with Prokofiev playing 12'27'': Prize giving ceremony with Prokofiev, Khachaturian, Shebalin etc. (soundless) 13'07'': Prokofiev at his dacha in 1946. Plays an extract from the Waltz Suite and is then interviewed (with sound) 15'36'': About the Association of Soviet Composers with an exhibition on Prokofiev. It shows extracts from the 1946 film. 16'46'': Repeat of the 1946 film with interview.

Notes: Abram Room’s Tonya tells the heroic story of a telephone operator who sacrifices her life by drawing Soviet artillery fire onto the Nazi weapons that are stored near her office. Like Room’s earlier film A Severe Young Man, Tonya was banned by the Soviet authorities. Prokofiev wrote the score in August 1942.

did.unittitle: Lermontov

note.p: Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: Albert Gendelshtein’s film is a portrait of the great nineteenth century Russian writer and poet Mikhail Lermontov, the inheritor of Pushkin’s mantle, who, like his mentor, died in a duel at the age of twenty six. Lermontov’s affection for the serfs and peasantry, and his criticisms of the Tsar, endeared him to the post-revolutionary Soviet regime. Prokofiev was one of two composers for the film (the other being Venedict Pushkov). Featuring Prokofiev’s two pieces, Contradance and Mephisto Waltz.

Notes: Programme: Strauss - Tod und Verklärung; Mahler - Rückert-Lieder; Prokofiev - Alexander Nevsky. Interval: 'Filming Nevsky' - Why did Stalin commission Eisenstein to make Alexander Nevsky in 1938? Vanora Bennett delves into the politics behind this cinematic masterpiece, with critic John Riley, Russian director Alexander Sokurov, and political historian Richard Taylor.

did.unittitle: BBC Radio 3 - Music Matters (23/02/2003)

note.p: Secondary creator: Including Vladimir Ashkenazy, Noelle Mann and David Nice
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: Programme (taken from playlist): REMAINS OF THE DAY: Berlioz's 200th anniversary has sparked a row over his final resting place. His fans are divided over whether his remains should be moved to the Panthéon in Paris. Hugh Schofield reports. GREAT PERFORMER: Dermot Clinch talks to pianist Murray Perahia. CRYING WOLF: To mark the hundredth anniversary of the death of Hugo Wolf, Dermot Clinch asks Susan Youens, Joan Rodgers, Rodger Vignoles and Christa Ludvig whether Wolf was the greatest lieder composer of all. PROKOFIEV ON TRIAL: This week marks the 50th anniversary of the death of Sergei Prokofiev. From Moscow, Nicholas Walton traces the life of the man. And Tommy Pearson talks to pianist and conductor Vladimir Ashkenavy, curator of the Prokofiev Archive Noëlle Mann and biographer David Nice about the impact of Stalinism on Prokofiev's music

did.unittitle: S. Prokofiev (dir. Lidia Stepanova); archival footage

note.p: Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: 1. Composer S. Prokofiev (dir. Lidia Stepanova) 2 i) "Kompozitor S. Prokof'eva, vozvrativshiisia v SSSR" [silent film of Prokofiev playing with Persimfans, 1927]. ii) Prize giving ceremony with Prokofiev, Khachaturian, Shebalin etc. (silent) iii) Prokofiev at his dacha in 1946. Plays an extract from the Waltz Suite and is then interviewed (with sound). Brief clip of Shostakovich iv) Performance of Piano Concerto No. 3; unidentified pianist and orchestra, conductor Kirill Kondrashin v) Section on Eisenstein. Shows plans and drawings for Ivan Grozny and a scene with Prokofiev at the piano
